page.title: 17Stone Stiles of Emborough
page.content: Stone stiles set in dry stone walls are a familiar sight at Emborough and neighbouring parishes where footpaths link hamlets an villages. They are constructed of a large slab of stone set vertically into the ground over which one has to climb, aided by steps of square blocks of stone on either side. These are cattleproof and easily maintainalbe. In the past these stiles and footpaths were used daily by farm and quary workers returning to and from their work. Today however it is mainlly ramblers that are seen to use them and therefore most are kept in place, maintained and cleared of biars and hedgerows that would otherwise engulf those which lie in fields off the beaten track.
